bibl.title: STATE OF NEBRASKA Twelfth Biennial Report OF THE Commandant OF THE Soldiers' and Sailors' Home To the Governor and the Board of Commissioners of State Institutions For the Biennium ending November 30, 1916

respStmt.name: OCLC Online Computer Library Center Inc.

p.seg: STATE OF NEBRASKA Twelfth Biennial Report OF THE Commandant OF THE Soldiers' and Sailors' Home MILFORD, NEBRASKA To the Governor and the Board of Commissioners of State Institutions For the Bicnnium ending November 30, 1916

198 SECOND BIENNIAL REPORT OF SOLDIERS' AND SAILORS' HOME To His Excellency, Honorable John H. Morehead, Governor, and to the Honorable members of the Board of Commis - sioners of State Institutions, Howard Kennedy, Henry Gerdes and Silas A. Holcomb: Gentlemen : KI have the honor to submit the twelfth biennial report the Soliers' and Sailors' Home, Milford, Nebraska. I In beginning this report I wish to express my gratitude the all-wise Providence for His goodness in preserving the moers of this "Home". tThe conditions existing in the "Home" and among the bers are the best. The food is of high quality and very cooked. We have done quite a bit of work in improving the Main Building. It has been painted from the top to bottom and new floors laid in all halls and rooms. An elevator also has been installed which runs from the basement to the top floor, saving many steps for the inmates. tThe new Hospital Building has been completed and has 1 occupied for the past six months. A new walk has been t around the new Hospital Building. kThe new Laundry Building is about ready to be occupied when completed, will be one of the best laundries in the institutions. tThe institution does not attempt to do much farming out - of gardening truck, such as green corn, field corn, po - !S, cabbage, cucumbers, beets, onions, radishes, etc. The en truck, fruit, etc., is used for the "Home". In favor- Milford, Nebraska

THE BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS 199 > I able seasons we have fruit, such as apples, cherries and plums. The pigs eat the refuse of the tables which is almost enough to keep them. When hogs are sold the money received is credited to the institution cash fund of the "Home". List of garden truck and other products raised the last two years: Cora 380 bushels @ $0.65 per bushel $247.00 Potatoes 750 bushels @ .70 per bushel 525.00 Cabbage 500 head ® .05 per head 25.00 Cucumbers 30 bushels © .60 per bushel 18.00 Beets 50 bushels @ .40 per bushel 20.00 Onions 50 bushels @ 2.00 per bushel 100.00 Total Hogs sold and now on hand: 32 hogs sold at $610.08 36 hogs on hand now, value about 70949 One old engine and parts sold to the Nebraska Soldiers' and Sail - ors' Home, Burkett, Nebraska for $213.00 One Generator sold to the Nebraska Corn Mills 100.00 Cinders sold to the amount of 11.25 I recommend that the following amounts be appropriated to meet the necessary expenses of the institution for the next biennium : I— Maintenance $ 70,000.00 (a) Salaries and Wages , _. 30,000.00 (b) General Repairs _ 15,000.00 II — New Equipment and Furniture 2,500.00 III — Permanent Improvements to Buildings and Grounds 1,000.00 IV— New Buildings and Grounds _ 15,000.00 Total _ $133,500.00 I have asked for $15,000 for new buildings for barn place to put wagon, machinery, hog shed, and ice plant, which. I think, would be a saving. Buildings and equipment would not cost much over $5,000. The old Hospita 1 Building needs repairs very much, should be plastered or some kind of cealine material put on and also needs painting. The porches on the Main Building need repairing and painting. In closing this report I wish to thank the Governor of the State, John H. Morehead, for the courtesy he has at all times shown me as Commandant of this "Home". I also

200 wish to thank the members of the Board of Commissioners of State Institutions for looking after the supplies that have been furnished and in granting every request that I have asked at their hand. I am also under obligations to the W. R. C. of the state for the many beautiful and useful gifts received from them. I have the honor to be, Yours very truly, D. C. Rowden, Commandant. Milford, Nebraska, November SO, 1916.
